metadata.case_name: Messrs. Sinha Govindji v. Joint Chief Controller of Imports & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner is a firm carrying on business of manufacture of celluloid and plastic bangles at Bellary, Mysore State; proprietor is citizen of India.

Two import licences granted: No. A 863296 dated January 18, 1960, and No. A 836640 dated February 2, 1960, each valued at Rs. 75,000 for importing cellulose nitrate sheets from Soft Currency area except South Africa; for periods April-September 1959 and October-March 1960.
Petitioner entered into firm commitments for import of cellulose sheets to the value of Rs. 99,000.
On March 4, 1960, petitioner received two letters from Assistant Controller of Imports, Madras, asking extent of licences utilised and not to enter fresh commitments without prior approval.
Correspondence ensued between petitioner and Control authorities.

On May 27, 1960, petitioner received two notices proposing cancellation of licences under cl.9 of Imports Control Order, 1955, without stating any grounds; directed not to enter commitments and return licences.
Petitioner replied on May 30, 1960, stating notice does not disclose grounds under cl.9, impossible to show cause without knowing ground, and no ground exists.
On August 3, 1960, orders passed cancelling the two licences, stating no sufficient cause furnished against notice dated May 27, 1960; no grounds stated in orders.
Cancellation led to Customs holding back petitioner's goods at port awaiting clearance, causing heavy demurrage.

After issue of licences, letter dated February 16, 1960, received from Director, Small Industries Service Institute, Bangalore, stating petitioner had no machinery/equipment to manufacture relevant articles from imported raw material.

Joint investigation by Assistant Director of Industries, Bellary, and Deputy Director, Small Industries Service Institute, Hubli; found no machinery/equipment at premises, no municipal/factory licence.

Chief Controller of Imports & Exports wrote to petitioner on July 2, 1960, informing of investigation findings, alleging fraudulent obtaining of Essentiality Certificate and licences; called upon to show cause within 15 days why further issue of licences should not be suspended under cl.8.

Petitioner received July 2 letter on July 5, 1960; solicitor wrote on July 15, 1960, asking copy of joint investigation report and other documents, stated would show cause upon receipt, requested personal hearing and no further action meantime.
No reply to July 15 letter until August 6, 1960 (after cancellation); no copy of report provided before cancellation.
On August 6, 1960, respondents replied requiring letter of authority from solicitor on stamped paper.
Solicitor submitted authority on August 10, 1960, protesting cancellation as arbitrary without opportunity.
Further correspondence on cl.8 action and challenging investigation report, including absence of machinery.

legal_issues.text: Whether the petitioner was given a reasonable opportunity of being heard before cancellation of licences, as required by cl.10 of Imports Control Order, 1955.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cancellation orders amounted to denial of reasonable opportunity of being heard under cl.10; notices dated May 27, 1960 did not state grounds under cl.9; letter dated July 2, 1960 related to suspension under cl.8, not cancellation under cl.9; no documents provided despite request; violated Art.19(1)(g).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Cl.10, Imports Control Order 1955; Art.19 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Letter dated July 2, 1960 stated grounds (fraud/misrepresentation via fake Essentiality Certificate, no machinery) and referred to prior notices/correspondence, thus complied with cl.10 for cancellation under cl.9; petitioner did not furnish sufficient cause.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Cl.9(a), Cl.10, Imports Control Order 1955; para 6(vii) Ch.V Import Trade Control Handbook 1956; Cl.8(b)

court_reasoning.text: Notice May 27, 1960 did not state grounds under cl.9; petitioner rightly pointed out inability to show cause without grounds. Letter July 2, 1960 primarily for cl.8 suspension, not clearly for cl.9 cancellation despite references; even if for cl.9, petitioner requested documents/hearing on July 15, no reply or documents provided before August 3 orders; orders falsely stated no cause shown when opportunity requested; clear violation of cl.10 and natural justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner had no reasonable opportunity of being heard before cancellation orders.

holdings.text: Cancellation orders dated August 3, 1960 are bad for violation of cl.10 requiring reasonable opportunity of being heard, and must be quashed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Enforcement of fundamental right to carry on business under Art.19; writ petitions under Art.32

statutes_cited.name: Imports Control Order, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Cl.9 grounds for cancellation (inadvertence, mistake, fraud, misrepresentation); Cl.10 requires reasonable opportunity of being heard before action under Cl.9; Cl.8 for suspension of further licences

statutes_cited.name: Import Trade Control Hand Book of Rules and Procedure, 1956

outcome.summary: Writ petitions allowed; cancellation orders dated August 3, 1960 quashed as petitioner not given reasonable opportunity of being heard in violation of cl.10 of Imports Control Order, 1955.

key_quotes.text: On a careful consideration of the facts and circumstances as stated in the affidavits of the parties we have come to the conclusion that the petitioner has had no reasonable opportunity of being heard before the cancellation orders were made on August 3, 1960. The cancellation orders are, therefore, bad and must be quashed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on violation of natural justice

key_quotes.text: There was, in our opinion, a clear violation of the requirement of cl. 10, which embodies the principles of natural justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Links statutory requirement to natural justice principles
